head_text.subj: A QUOTATION AGAINST A BLACK SCREEN
'REJOICE, O YOUNG MAN, IN THY YOUTH ...'

text: The sound now of a C-130 air cargo plane roaring over us cut sharply to:
As the C-130 coasts to a stop, the hatch rotating down on dusty lifeless airstrip somewhere in Vietnam.  Nothing se live or move in the midday sun.

A DOZEN NEW RECRUITS step off the plane, unloading their bags, looking around like only the new can look around, t hair regulation-clipped, crisp, new green fatigues fittin like cardboard. CHRIS TAYLOR is just another one of them - as he turns in tight closeup, to look at a motorized cart pulling up alo ... He's about 21.  Newmeat.  His face, unburned yet by t is tense, bewildered, innocent, eyes searching for the tr They fall now on a heap of BODY BAGS in the back of the c Two soldiers begin loading them onto the plane.  Flies - of flies - buzz around them, the only cue to their conten
(next to Chris, Southern accent) That what I think it is?
(a look) I guess so ... An uncomfortable look between them.

Okay, let's go ... As they move out, Chris' eyes moving with the body bags b loaded onto the plane.  Moving over now to a motley HALF VETERANS bypassing them on their way to the plane.  They happy.  Very happy, chatting it up. They pass the newboys - and they shake their heads, their full of an almost mocking pity.

Well I'll be dipped in shit - new meat!  Sorry bout  that boys - 'sin loi' buddy ... you gonna love the  Nam, man, for-fucking-ever. Chris looking at them.  They pass, except for the last ma walks slower than the rest, a slight limp.  His eyes fall Chris. They're frightening eyes, starved, hollow, sunken deep in face, black and dangerous.  The clammy pallor of malaria to him as he looks at Chris through decayed black teeth. the sun flares out on him and he's past.  And Chris looks Disturbed.  It's as if the man was not real.  For a momen As if he were a ghost. Chris walking, duffel bag on the shoulder, looks up at th lollipop sun burning a hole through the sky.  A rushing S now.  Of frightening intensity, an effect combining the b an airplane with the roar of a lion as we hardcut to:

The sun matches the intensity of the previous shot as we down into thick green jungle.  We hear the sound of MEN c lot of men.  The thwack of a machete.  Brush being bulled wait.  They are getting close. The CREDITS continue to run. SUBTITLE reads: December 1967 - Bravo Company, 25th Infan Division - Somewhere near the Cambodian Border. A sweating white face comes into view. CHRIS - cutting po Machete in one hand, whacking out a path for the platoon, the other, he looks like he's on the verge of heat exhaus Breathing too hard, pacing himself all wrong, bumping int things, tripping, not quite falling, he looks pathetic he the naturalness of the jungle.  An urban transplant, slig neurotic and getting more so. His rucksack is coming apart as well, about 70 badly pack pounds banging noisily. Behind him BARNES now comes, the Platoon Sergeant.  Then his radio man, humming lightly.  Others are behind, the c snaking back deep into the brush. We cut around some FACES of the Platoon - all to be seen Young faces, hard and dirty after weeks in the field, exh yet alert, fatigues filthy, slept-in, torn, personalized, way past regulation length, medals, bandanas.  A jungle a Boys. Chris glancing down at his raw bleeding blisters. Transfe machete to his other, slightly less blistered, hand.  The cuts on - struggling but trying, on his last reserves of  strength, smashing almost straight forward through brush, even bothering to look ahead.  He smells something, looks slows his pace, eyes working ... around to the base of a He moves past it. And as he does so, the camera from his POV comes around o decomposing 10-day-old GOOK - eyes starting from its sock worms and flies feasting. Chris draws his breath in, terrified.  Barnes suddenly ap alongside, his hard humourless eyes looking annoyed from to Chris.
What are you waiting for?  He ain't gonna bite you.   Move out. Chris looks at him with pent-up hatred and crashes on.
At the COMPANY PC, CAPTAIN HARRIS on the radio.
Bravo Two, Six.  What's the delay up there, move it  out on point.  We've got a link up at Phase Line  Whiskey at One Eight Zero Zero, over.
At the PLATOON PC, LIEUTENANT WOLFE sweats heavily as he in his radio.  He is also new to the field, a dark little guy, about 24, very hairy, especially in the eyebrows, an get-ahead look.
Two Bravo, Two move it out.  Six says we're jamming  'em up back there.  Over. Barnes, upfront, turns to SAL, his radio man, under his b

Tell that dipshit to get fucked.  Get that other  freshmeat up here.  Gardner. As Barnes picks up his pace, irritated now at this reprim the CO - coming up on Chris, who is soaked now from head in sweat, dizzy, feeling sick, about to vomit.

What the hell's the matter with you Taylor!  You a  sorry ass motherfucker.  Fall back. He grabs Chris's machete out of his hand and bulls his wa the foliage, tearing it apart, setting a new pace. Chris being bypassed by the column, their eyes on him.  H swatting at the red ants that are all over his neck. GARDNER, another new recruit, fat, hustling up to replace A big and black medic - DOC - comes over, gentle eyes and with him is Sergeant ELIAS, concerned.
You okay?
Ants.  I got ants on my neck ... (shaking them out)

(helping him) Yeah, black ants are killers, you look sick man.  You  need a little salt. (reaching into his satchel) Sergeant Elias, a handsome, graceful dark-haired Indian k 23, the squad sergeant, is taking items out of Chris' pac mattress, extra unnecessary clothing, extra canteens, gre gas mask, books.

(shaking his head, amused) You're humping way too much, troop, don't need half  this shit.  I'll haul it for you but next time you  check it out with me okay? Chris nodding, grateful, panting. The men passing, watching.  Chris sorry about this, tryin keep up face. BUNNY, a young 18 year-old with an angel's face, is pissi the dead gook's face. KING passes, glances at him.

You're a sick mother Bunny. Bunny laughing about it. Chris standing there one moment, fighting for his breath, suddenly passes out, going over with his 70 pound rucksac hitting the ground with a loud bang.
(concerned) Hold it up. On Chris - his eyes opening.  He seems all right.
(trying to get up) I'm okay ... I'm okay. Chris crumples backwards.  Elias helps him.

The COMPANY - about 100 men who seem insignificant amid t of the surrounding jungle - is digging into a perimeter o 100-yard radius.  A RESUPPLY CHOPPER lifts off in a flurr blowing leaves.  Bare-chested soldiers chop down trees, c fields of fire, set out claymores, fill sandbags, chow do Little fires snake up against the greying red horizon.
We cut close on a pair of grungy feet - the staple of the infantry - moving up to DOC, the Medic, bandaging them fo SHENG, a Hawaiin kid.
Rhah sets his tripflare.  Crawford, with him, putting out claymore.
Back in the perimeter RODRIGUEZ sets his M-60 in the newl foxhole.  SAL, next to him, is shaving in his helmet.

KING looks like a king.  A lion of a black man but with a gentle face, not to be roused, is painfully trying to scr letter home with the pencil held awkwardly, mouthing the FRANCIS, a young baby-faced black with long lashes and so peeks over his shoulder, shaking his head.
Shit, King, it ain't d-e-r-e man, it's d-e-a-r, and  Sara don't have no two r's in it, fool.  Shame on  you. King shrugs, a sleepy stoned voice.
Don't matter, she knows what it means ... an she  don't read too good nohow ...

Sgt. Elias washes himself, attentive to his body, slender well-muscled, and extremely handsome youth.  Of Indian bl with long black hair, generous smile, wide facial bone st gypsy eyes, and the cleanest white teeth, he could be a y Greek god.  He is given somewhat to panache, a silver wri on his arm, a bandana of black parachute silk hanging fro neck, his fatigues tightened down at the ankle, he pulls pants down, checking for crotch rot, applying talcum powd the area, his buttocks facing us. LERNER, a white kid, 19, from Florida, stopping to admire frontal view.
Mumm, any time sweetheart.
Lerner, you'd choke to death on it.

At the COMPANY COMMAND POST a beehive of activity with it radios, personnel, some Vietnamese scouts milling around. CAPTAIN HARRIS is running down a field map with his THREE LIEUTENANTS.  Harris, a broad-shouldered fine-looking mil specimen with the requisite Southern accent and football mannerism, is directing his remark to 2nd Platoon's LT.WO looks a little nervous.

Sky Six reports a fresh company of NVA moving across  from Cambodia to this blue line. (points to position) We got a good chance to light 'em up tonight.  All  platoons will set squad-size ambushes before full  dark.  Lt. Wolfe (glances at him) You 'bush in this area near that ol' Buddhist temple  we passed on the hump in.  Lt. Hawkins, you take this  area in the rubber plantation...
(eager) No problem sir ...
Elsewhere, Chris scrapes out a foxhole, his shirt off, ba around his head, the work hot and heavy. TEX is out there setting the claymore as BIG HAROLD and J start breaking down their C's.
(a whining high voice) Hey Big Harold, gimme your peaches for the fruitcake  man.
(laughes loudly) Fuck you bitch.
C'mon man, didn't I do you right that time I give you  the turkey loaf for the ham and lima beans shit.

Tricky bitch, reason you gimme dat turkey loaf is  nobody else can eat that shit 'cept me so don't start  your game playing with me Junior. They're both black, Junior with huge goggle eyes and a fa pimples and pockmarks, his teeth yellowed and decayed, so them missing.  Harold is about twice his size, about 250 a baby huey concentrating real hard on preparing his stov with.
Youse a pig man.  I hope Manny get dat laundry gig  for' you do.
De fool think he's gonna get it but he ain't known  for his thinking.
He's a fool alright but you a bigger fool.  Hey,  whiteboy, watcha waiting for - dat hole ain't gonna  dig itself ... Chris looks up, continues working, as Junior chuckles.
Hey Taylor, you don't know it but I saved your ass  today.  I killed a shit-eating dog. (laughing)
(getting up) That reminds me, I gotta take a shit.
You gonna wipe your ass dis time?
Yeah if you let me have your shirt.

(VOICE OVER, as he digs) Somebody once wrote Hell is the impossibility of  Reason.  That's what this place feels like.  I hate  it already and it's only been a week.  Some goddamn  week, grandma ... (checking his raw blisters) ... the hardest thing I think I've ever done is to go  on point, 3 times this week - I don't even know what  I'm doing.  A gook could be standing 3 feet in front  of me and I wouldn't know it, I'm so tired.  We get  up at 5 a.m., hump all day, camp around 4 or 5 p.m.,  dig foxhole, eat, then put out an all-night ambush or  a 3-man listening post in the jungle.  It's scary  cause nobody tells me how to do anything cause I'm  new and nobody cares about the new guys, they don't  even want to know your name.  The unwritten rule is a  new guy's life isn't worth as much cause he hasn't  put his time in yet - and they say if you're gonna  get killed in the Nam it's better to get it in the  first few weeks, the logic being: you don't suffer  that much.  I can believe that ... If you're lucky  you get to stay in the perimeter at night and then  you pull a 3-hour guard shift, so maybe you sleep 3-4  hours a night, but you don't really sleep ... I don't  think I can keep this up for a year, grandma - I  think I've made a big mistake coming here ... As he speaks, we cut around to various shots of the plato members on the perimeter - shaving, eating, cooking, play ...

Towards the end of this voice over, we cut to Sgt. BARNES towards the PLATOON PC.  A powerful face, a quiet, angry stare, a thick trimmed moustache that helps conceal a net plastic surgery grafts and scars.  The distortion from th the left side of his face to his forehead, punctuated by indentation above the left eye where a bullet once penetr skull. Walking with him is Sgt. O'NEILL as they join WOLFE, Sgts and WARREN at the PLATOON PC where they're huddled over m Warren is a black, thin, tall, paranoid man with untrusti silent and bitter.
(to all, almost pleased about it) We got boo-coo movement.  3rd Battalion just got hit  15 kliks north of here. (the MEN react with wary silence)
(eager to elaborate) Yeah, they had claymores strung up in the trees, blew  a whole fucking platoon to pieces.  BAAD SHIT. Barnes inflects his next words at Wolfe, who is worried.
Yeah, they got two Lieutenants and a Captain.
Jesus. Elias quiet.  Barnes studying the map.

(to Barnes) Who do you want on ambush, Sergeant? Barnes doesn't bother acknowledging the question, barely at the Lieutenant, to him a necessary evil.  Everybody kn who's really in charge of the Platoon.  Barnes flicks his Elias.
Elias - you take your squad and I'll take Tex and  Francis from your squad. (to Warren) We move out in two-zero mikes. (concluding)
I thought it was O'Neill's turn tonight. They all look at each other.  O'Neill spits in the dust, freckled, short red head with a hard worried face, a life going on 60.
Shit!  Morehouse and Sal are short.  Fu Sheng's going  on R&R, you don't want to send their asses out on an  ambush.  You got the fresh meat Elias.
(to Barnes) They don't know shit Barnes, and chances are we gonna  run into something.
So what am I going to do!  Get one of my guys zapped  so some fuckface fresh from the World can get his  beauty fucking sleep!
Hey O'Neill why don't you cool it, you don't have to  be a prick everyday of your life, you know.
Fuck you Elias.
You get your men ready Elias ... Concluding the debate, no further argument, Barnes rises. meeting's closed.  Lt. Wolfe hasn't said a word, looking departs, without a word.

(watching him) Fucking guy's got 3 years in and he thinks he's  Cochise or something ... His resentment directed partly at the way in which Elias himself, the natural sense of grace - and the dignity it
Later.  On the very edge of the perimeter, darkness comin fast, the men in the ambush patrol rustle into their pack of them bitching. Tex, carrying the M-60, looks up at the glowering sky.
Shit, looks like rain.  All night too.  Gonna grow  mushrooms in your bad-ass crotch Junior.
(under his breath) Goddamn ain't no justice round here, you break your  ass for de white man ... gonna get our act together,  do some rappin' wid de brothers, change things ...
What's O'Neill have a nose up the lieutenant's ass  already, how come we always get ambush.

Politics, man, politics.  We always getting fucked  around here. Chris is scared, nervous with his last-minute equipment  adjustments, his pack obviously overweight for a night mi he hauls it up. Gardner, the other new boy, is jovial in contrast, his wa extended towards Chris.
Hey Chris, I show you a picture of Lucy Jean?

(not to be bothered) No ... Gardner shows him his girl.  She's real dog u-g-l-y, and makes it worse is Gardner's put the standard photo of Raq Welch alongside it, tits and all.  But he misses the iron
(admiring) Yeah she's the one all right ... that's Lucy Jean.   She's a-waiting for me.

(nodding) Yeah she's real pretty, you're lucky ... Gardner puts it away.  Elias appears alongside them, chec their packs out, takes out Chris's poncho liner and other He carries a modified M-16 with a short barrel and a coll stock.

(to both boys) Don't need this or this ... you're doing okay.  Just  stick close to Tex, do what he does. (calling out to Tex) Tex you got Junior and Taylor here on your position. Tex is a sour Texas Ranger type, chews tobacco, spits.
Damn, 'Lias this gun's boss.  Put Taylor someplace  else. Chris feels the words like lashes on him.

You got Taylor ... (to Gardner) ... Gardner you go with me (to Chris and Gardner) 'Case somethin' happens to you, you get separated or  lost don't yell out okay.  Sit tight.  We'll get to  you. His eyes.  Chris watching them.  A smile in them.  Elias off, a quality to the man that Chris admires.  A natural leadership.
Okay, let's move out. As he follows King, on point, out the perimeter.  A singl

Night is coming down.  The tone of the jungle sounds has shifted - mellower, more sinuous and certainly scarier. The file stops.  King, an experienced point man, listens. Chris - carrying Tex's linked ammo - looks around, tense. him is Gardner, trying to smile, starts to whisper someth ('Hey Taylor ...') when he's abruptly shushed. The file moves on.  Gardner's pack rattling a little too weird rush of cold wind now rattles the trees and the MON comes.  A hard slanting rain, sudden, tropic.

A piece of an old Buddhist temple, under a sulky moonligh a state of decay, the jungle surging to engulf it. The Men are setting up quickly and relatively quietly in ruins - alongside a miniscule trail.  The rain is coming harder than ever. Chris and Tex setting out their claymore mines, raveling their detonating cords to their position, drenched.  In t distance, an ILLUMINATION ROUND brightens the sky for a b moment.  Various ad lib curses and directions are lost in sound of the rain.
At the Ambush CP, Ace whipsers into his radio.  A soft hi sound.
Later.  Close on Chris being shaken awake.
Taylor, you're on.
(groggy) Uh hunh. The rain continuing to pelt them.  Tex hands him an infra scope.
(suspicious) You sure you know how to work the claymore?
(offended) Sure. Tex curls up as best he can in his poncho to sleep.
Okay ... don't catch no zzz's on me buddy or I'll  sling your motherfucking ass ... You hear me?
(grits his teeth) Yeah. (looking at his watch) Hey Tex - you're ten minutes fast.

Sin Loi. ('tough luck', closes his teeth) Chris lets it go, scans the jungle and trail with the sco POV is greasy and blurred.  He puts it aside. Suddenly a series of resonant SNORES crack through the ju Chris starts, then sees it's from JUNIOR lying out there, spreadeagled in the rain.  Chris prods him.
Junior!
Unh? ... Unh.
Shaddup!  You're snoring ... Shhh. Bending low into his eardrum.  Junior never wakes, rolls with a growl.  Silence.
Later.  A pool of muddy water has formed, in which a pair buttocks sit.  Move up to Chris still on duty, looking at watch, drawn, drenched, pathetic, rainwater coursing down face.

(continuing his letter) ... 'Course Mom and Dad didn't want me to come, they  wanted me to be just like them - respectable, hard- working, making $200 a week, a little house, a  family.  They drove me crazy with their goddamn  world, grandma, you know Mom, I don't want to be a  white boy on Wall Street, I don't want my whole life  to be predetermined by them. A large RIPPING SOUND as the wind blows down a big tree b onto the jungle floor.  He starts, peering out.  Nothing. looks at his watch again.

... I guess I have always been sheltered and special,  I just want to be anonymous.  Like everybody else.   Do my share for my country.  Live up to what Grandpa  did in the First War and Dad the Second.  I know this  is going to be the war of my generation.  Well here I  am - anonymous all right, with guys nobody really  cares about - they come from the end of the line,  most of 'em, small towns you never heard of -  Pulaski, Tennessee, Brandon, Mississippi, Pork Bend,  Utah, Wampum, Pennsylvania.  Two years' high school's  about it, maybe if they're lucky a job waiting for  'em back in a factory, but most of 'em got nothing,  they're poor, they're the unwanted of our society,  yet they're fighting for our society and our freedom  and what we call America, they're the bottom of the  barrel - and they know it, maybe that's why they call  themselves 'grunts' cause a 'grunt' can take it, can  take anything.  They're the backbone of this country,  grandma, the best I've ever seen, the heart and soul  - I've found it finally, way down here in the mud -  maybe from down here I can start up again and be  something I can be proud of, without having to fake  it, maybe ... I can see something I don't yet see,  learn something I don't yet know ... I miss you, I  miss you very much, tell Mom I miss her too - Chris. He moves towards Junior, shakes him, but Junior seems to of this world.
Wake up! Junior opens one dead eye.

It's your shift, man ... Junior scowls, swears, looks around for his rifle in the Chris crawls back to his position, curling himself up in soaked poncho, teeth chattering from the cold, rain splat over him.  A long beat.  He sighs, the sigh kicking off t image.

Chris jerks awake - very suddenly, very frightened.  THE STOPPED.  The jungle sounds are loud.  Cicadas, night ani water dripping hypnotically from leaf to leaf.  And the w a million mosquitoes out after the rains, chewing at Chri He looks around, startled. Tex is asleep.  Junior is asleep.  What happened?  He loo his watch.  The mosquitoes are eating him alive.  He buri head in his green towel which he wears around his neck, b can't see.  A beat.  He moves again, miserable from the b Another beat.  Then suddenly the sounds of the jungle shi some of the animals dropping out.  A different tone.  A p wood is stepped on, a rustle of bush ... Chris sees something, lifts an edge of the towel to peek A shoadow of a figure is frozen there in front of him abo yards.  It looks like a man.  But it doesn't move.  At al listens. Chris, his heart in his mouth, tries to peer through it. bush.  It has to be.  No human being could stand that sti heartbeats are up.  The moments take forever.  But deep d somewhere in his psyche - he knows who it is. The figure now shifts, ever so slightly - and moves.  It human being.  Oh my God! Chris looks around.  Tex seems like a mile away.  Why doe anyone fire!  He casts a desperate look at his rifle, at grenades encrusted with mud, but in spite of all his trai is frozen with indecision and fear at the sight of his en The figure seems to whisper something back, then turns an down the trail.  Now a second and third figure appear beh - all in helmets and packs.  All coming right past Chris' position.  Ten yards.  Nine. Chris is rigid with terror.  Stark eyes.  Pleading with T wake up, but out of reach.  He is about to have an anxiet attack, his heartbeats so far up he is sure they will hea The first figure is now directly in front of Chris on the looking left and right.  A rattle of his equipment, a cre leather.  A smell.  The man's face now catches the moonli his eyes come around on Chris. Oriental eyes.  Looking right at him.  Startled.  Chris s back, hypnotized.  It all happens very fast.  The figure something in Vietnamese.  A warning.  He swivels. A flash of muzzle fire.  A raking cough of automatic fire grenade explosion. Chris is hurled to the ground, helmet bouncing off, scatt confused, jarred.  All hell breaks loose around him with and SHOUTS. Tex, kissing the ground, is yelling at him.
Chris, not knowing what he's doing, is fumbling with the handles, presses them.  INSERT: They won't give.  He trie and again to the squeeze the life out of them.  Tex is sc at him.

Lunges over and grabs the handle from Chris.  Clicks the off and blows them. Three EXPLOSIONS rip out into the night - and one of the caught in a brief instant looking like an X-ray, his body and swirling in the air, then enveloped in swirls of smok Chris, trying to keep up, grabs his M-16, lays out a stre fire.  The sound all around him is deafening.
Gardner, freaking out, stands crouched, confused, tries t collapses.
O'Neill throws a grenade, wild.
An explosion.  Chris hits the deck. Tex is now on the M-60 machine gun, yelling at Junior who cringing on the ground.
Feed me! He lays out red tracer bullets like laser beams, then sud reels back, whiplashed, screaming.  A grenade explosion r them.
His hand and wrist are gone, his face in the dirt.  Junio fumbling around, trying to stay down and help him at the time.
(grabbing Tex's gun)
Chris, looking out to his front, has no clue what's going Except the fire is slacking.  Relayed shouts of 'Medic! M Other SHOUTS.
The firing has ceased.  A silence, punctuated by occasion shouts and fast moments, has enveloped once more the ceme Doc crashes through the bush, kneels over Tex, who contin howl in deep pain.
(freaked out)
Easy Tex easy boy! Trying to sound calm but his voice is on the edge, examin mutilation with a pen flashlight, he whips out his morphi big hypodermic.
(next position) Doc over here!  Gardner's hit.
'Right there. As he slips the morphine into Tex's arm.

(muttering at Chris) ... godamn!  Godamn!  DUMB FUCKER, DUMB FUCKER! Chris watching, suddenly feels himself dizzy, instinctive his hands over the back of his neck.  Feels the warm bloo A moan comes from his lips.  Junior looks at him.
Oh shit, Doc he's hit too.

(weakly) I'm hit ... Barnes and Big Harold come hustling up. Doc finishes tourniquetting Tex, cradles Chris onto the e his flashlight probing the wound.  Tex in background cont thrash and moan. Chris waits, tensely for the verdict, his eyes big with f Doc, who takes out his morphine.
(to Barnes, pointing at Chris) That dumb fuck didn't blow his claymore! Chris hearing this.  Barnes looks at him.
(to Chris) ... it's a scratch, nothing to worry about.
(suspicious) Doc ... tell me the truth, don't lie to me. The needle goes in.  Tex lets out this strange keening mo sets everyone's teeth on edge.
(to Barnes) He let'em walk right up on us.  He was sleeping on  his shift.
(muttering weakly) I was not ... it was your ...

(leaving, to Harold and Junior) Self-preservation's the first law of nature.  Gotta  learn how to work your shit Taylor.  Watch me, don't  let'em go into shock. Tex's moans are maddening and scary.  Barnes suddenly cla hand over Tex's mouth shutting him up and from way down d his throat, chokes out the words.

Shut up!  Shut up - and TAKE IT!  TAKE THE PAIN! Tex's eyes roll wildly, uncomprehending.  Doc and Big Har looking at Barnes, wondering.  Tex is suddenly silent, sh Barnes stands, an icy glare, goes.  Junior scrambles over Tex's side.  Doc runs off. Big Harold cradles Chris, his big black hands like a moth reassuring him.
You gonna be okay Taylor, okay, don't you start  worrying now. Chris looking up at him, eyes blinking slowly, dazed alre the morphine.  He's very scared.
Do you ... do you know you're gonna die ... Big  Harold? ... do you feel like ... like ...  everything's gonna be fine and then ...

Bullshit man, you gettin outta the field, man.  Three  hots a day, white sheets, dem pretty white nurses  give you blowjobs too you pay em enough, I heard tell  bout dem white bitches.  Better save yo strength  Taylor.
(muttering darkly) Don babytalk him man.  Cocksucker fell asleep.  They  walked right up on us, he don do shit.
Shaddup bitch. Chris is gettin woozier, feeling he is dying but starting grin, not caring about it anymore.  Yet he is nowhere clo dying.
It's not ... so bad ... dying.  How long .. it ...
Barnes stands over a moaning, ripped up ENEMY SOLDIER.  F M-16 point blank into the head.  The Soldier bucks and di quivering.
ELIAS, checking out a blood trail some distance away, shi the shot, looks back.
FRANCES, MANNY, BUNNY and KING are huddled over another m enemy corpse.
(stripping the corpse) That's no NVA man.  That's a chink - look at 'em, the  cocksucker's six and a half feet tall.  Look at his  gear - good as ours.
Shit I blew my claymore right in one dude's face and  I seen him walking around afterwards.
What we fighting here, vampires?
Elias comes up to Barnes swiftly, indicating the blood tr leading off into the bush.
Blood trail just keeps going and going but no body.
How the hell did he get away?
Fuckers returned fire soon as we lit 'em up.  Hard  core fuckin' NVA.  They got their shit together.

(coming up to Barnes) Sarge - Doc wants you.  There's a problem with the  new man. Elias and Barnes go with King.  Past Chris and Tex who ar ambulatory and bandaged, being helped along.  As Barnes p the men look at him, everybody quickly senses something i

At one of the positions Doc is working feverishly to knoc life back into Gardner who lies there, his shirt stripped his cottage cheese belly.  A huge sucking chest wound.  H dying.  You know it because he knows it.  The eyes do the talking, numb, terrorized yet strangely detached, accepti protesting or concerned any longer. Most of the ambush has assembled and is watching, Chris m to see.  Doc is mumbling to him, low key.

Chopper's on the way Gardner, hang in there, you  gonna be okay ... But Gardner seems unconcerned.  Things are going on in hi who knows what.  And in his eyes there are big tears roll Then a morphine smile.  A sort of goofy Gardner smile, ma thinking about Lucy Jean, who knows.  He's dead.

(to all) Take a good look at this lump o'shit ... (motions to Gardner's body) Rmember what it looks like, all of you.  You fuck up  in a firefight and I guaran-goddamn-tee you, a trip  out of the bush - IN A BODYBAG.  Out here, assholes,  you keep your shit wired tight at ALL times ... (glares directly at Chris) and that goes for you, shit for brains.  You don't  SLEEP ON NO FUCKIN' AMBUSH.  Next sonofabitch I catch  coppin' z's in the bush I'm personally gonna take an  interest in seeing him suffer - I SHIT YOU NOT ... He thumps Chris lightly but menacingly in his chestbone a on.

(pissed, cuts in, shoves him hard) Shut your face chicken shit!  You in big trouble boy!
Excuses are like assholes, Taylor - everybody got  one.
Knock it off!  We got two men need attention here.   Police up your extra ammo and frags, don't leave  nothing for the dinks.  Hoyt, Junior, carry Gardner.

Chris is driven up in a jeep to his Company PC - marked ' PC' on a C-ration box.  It's midday on a hot lazy afterno people out in the 102 degree sun. Chris' Company is on the outskirts of the base camp, thei barracks regulation wood, canvas, and fine mesh screening dust everywhere, bunkers down on the perimeter, reams of wire and concertina, a sand-bagged MESS HALL and CHAPEL, mortar pits, observation towers, recoiless rifles, 50-cal machine guns. Chris gets out of the jeep, stiff-necked, a bandage aroun still in some pain.  The first man he intersects is KING, carrying crates of beer.
Hey Taylor, what's in the breeze? In King's mild tone Chris tries to read his standing in t platoon.
Okay - got light duty, three days.
Shit, too bad we in base camp anyway.
What you got there - beers?

Yeah, just stole me some from the Top's supply but  he's stealing it from us anyway. (sees somebody coming) Chucks are coming.  You better 'didi' man. Too late.  Sgt. O'NEILL, the redhead lifer accompanied by SANDERSON, a big handsome blond kid, not too bright in th both slightly drunk, come around a corner, beer cans in h O'Neill sees Chris immediately.
Hey Taylor - you back?
(pause) Uh, looks like it?
(spotting King's beer) Where'd you get that beer King?
(a funny look) I found it ...
You found it? ... Bullshit!  You going on report.   Gimmee that shit.
Awright, come here both of you.  You too Taylor (wags his finger) Got a little special job for you. They advance toward him reluctantly.
I got light duty, Sarge.  Doctor said to take it easy  couple days.
(laughes) ... ain't that tough shit now.

A wooden cabin with some half-dozen seats built over half cut from empty oil drums.  A guy is in there, pulling up pants. Chris, King and Crawford, a California blond with a hands honeyed look, are sweeating heavily as they roll the barr from under the outhouse, the smell of human waste strong. midday emptiness, nobody around except the flies.
(pissed) ... Motherfuckah, motherfuckah, I'm too short to be  dealing with this shit!  They keep fucking with us  man, no letup ...
(equally pissed) Politics man, fuckin' politics.  That O'Neill man got  his nose so far up Top's ass he gotta be Pinocchio...
Forty-two days man and a wakeup and I'm a gone  motherfucker.  Back to de WORLD. (dreaming in his eyes)
Broke a 100.  Got 92 to go.  April 17.  DEROS man.   California this summer.  Waves are good they tell me,  surfin's gonna be good ...
March man in Tennessee, sniff the pines ... sniff  that crossmounted pussy walkin' down by the river.   What you got Taylor? (a snicker) Let's see three hundred and WHAT?
(groans) Oh man!  Sorry bout that.  I can't even remember when  I was 332.  You gotta count backwards like you got 40  days in - think positive.
(to Chris) How the fuck you get over here man, you look like you  educated ...
I volunteered.
You WHAT?  Say 'gain.
Yeah, I dropped out of college and told 'em I wanted  infantry, combat, and Nam ... He grins, finding their reactions funny.  It's also the f time we've seen Chris crack a smile.
You volunteered for this shit man?
You a crazy fucker, givin' up college man. King has long sleepy eyelids and cat's eyes, a large pink and big white-edged cotton picker's nails - a lazy, gentl nature, content with the world.
Didn't make much sense.  Wasn't learning anything ... (hesitates) And why should just the poor kids go to the war - and  the college kids get away with it. King and Crawford share a smile.
What we got here a crusader?
Sounds like it. They pause, wipe the sweat off.  King lighting up a half- joint, hitting a few puffs, eyes shooting around, making he's not spotted, passing it to Crawford.

Sheeit, gotta be rich in the first place to think  like dat.  Everybody know the poor always being  fucked by the rich.  Always have, always will. Noticing Chris is having trouble with his neck, picking a bandage.
You okay man?  Neck botherin' you?
Nah ...
Here have some of this.  Won't feel a thing. Chris looking at the joint, a little apprehensive.  He's smoked.
No, thanks ...
Go on, whatcha gotta lose, yo' here now ...
Kills the smell of shit anyway. The joint proferred.  Chris waits a beat, shrugs, takes i smokes.
Suck it in.  Hold it ... That's it.  Now let it out. Chris blows it out.
Don't feel it. King and Crawford chuckle, go on rolling the cans.
Dat's what they all say.

King, Crawford and Chris pour kerosene over the cans at a distance from the outhouse. King lights it.  The cans pop and start crackling.  A lin burning barrels.  Rings of dirty black smoke rise against blue sky. They watch, stoned.  Chris turns to both of them.
... you know that night we got hit ... I ... (ashamed)
Fuck it, don't mean nothing, no such thing here as a  coward, done your best man, next time y'do better.
History, man, history. Chris surprised at their attitude.  The joint suddenly hi a look in his face, eyes looking around different.  Over
(deadpans) I think I'm starting to feel that stuff ... Crawford laughes.
(laughes) Yo getting there Taylor.  You be cool now and I'll  introduce you 'round to some of the 'heads'.
What are the heads?
(laughes, walks away with Crawford) Later ... Chris alone, breathes deep, feeling the full effect.
A relief against the long harsh, hot day.  We see lights over the camp, sounds of music, laughter from the barrack

King leads Chris down to a specially constructed cellar-l hutch dug deep into the ground on an isolated edge of the battalion perimeter.  Ammo casing and canvas are piled ov and sandbags surround it.  From the outside very little s be heard as they go down through a trap door made of ammo Past a lookout (Adams) pulling security, hitting a joint alert.  King motions to him, it's cool. Inside is another world.  Chris looking around amazed.  I a private cabaret for the 'heads' who are there cooling o Boxes of food from the States, beers, whiskey bottles, cr functioning as tables, hammocks hanging from poles, elect fans, tape decks, paraphenalia. The boys are all dressed up in their Saturday night rags. clothes are clean, the headbands, the medallions are out, anything distinctive and individualistic.  On the tapedec Jefferson Airplane's 'Go Ask Alice'. To Chris it is a new world.  And RHAH, the resident head, there in all his finery puffing a huge burning red bowl i three foot long Montagnard pipe, seems to be the lord of judgement in this smoky underworld. Across his naked chest, birds and snakes are tatooed.  Ar neck a black skull and white ivory cross side by side.  O knuckles 'Love' and 'Hate' are tattooed.  In his eyes, a Satanic fire.  A poor rural Southern white, in his grizzl 20's, he could be a Biker King.  Giving Chris the once-ov
Whatcha doing in the underworld Taylor?
(smiling) This ain't Taylor.  Taylor been shot.  This man Chris  been resurrected ... Chris wondering what he's doing here.  His eyes roving ov

Oooh Chris, you look like you is high oh yeah, he  looks like he is high Ooooh Chris, you know you gonna  be that way all night oh yeah I think that you are  ... Yeah! up now and up to par oh yeah. Elias pulls out a Remington 870 shotgun, jacks it to the points it at Chris.

Put your mouth on that. Chris does so slowly, a little worried.  Elias takes a hi blows it down the bore - 'shotgunning' it into Chris' lun Chris staggers back, coughing.  Everybody laughes 'hey du done had your ass blown away' etc ... Elias smiles his big white-tooth smile.

Then the worm has definately turned for you man. Chris puzzled by this expression.
(smiles) Feel good?

Feelin' good's good enough. As he sucks in a huge mass of smoke off the bowl.  His ey performing a funny little hop, skip and jump, as he holds face turning red. The monkey jabbers and jumps around on his neck, worried. then blows the smoke out in its face, the monkey hating i The Group laughes.
Hey Crutcher.  I hear you got a Dear John from your  gal.  Told you she wasn't getting 'nuff from you. Lerner looks up, stoned out of his mind, wearing a ring i ear.
Shit.  Sold me out for some lame dude with a 4-F.

(recalling her image) Daisy Mae.
Hey look at Charlotte! The monkey is sitting quietly stoned, its eyes blinking. Laughter off.
Daisy Mae!  What Daisy Mae look like Crutcher?
She look huge and got freckles on her ass.
She look beautiful.
How much she weigh man?
She braid her hair under her armpits, Crutcher.
(sarcastic) Daisy Mae what?
Daisy Mae Highway, that's what. (laughing) Well whatcha want, Lerner, your dick been limp for a  year, 'cept when you're bopping your buddy Tony up  there.
Fuck that.

I fucked this chick in Hawaii man.  Couple weeks ago  ... Oooooh!  Wow - outasight.  Gracie Slick man, she  looked like Gracie man, I shit you not. (remembering) The look on his face ensnares all of them, except perhaps

No whorehouse man.  On the beach.
Sure.

I just stopped man.  My heart's beating like a hardon  right I got a hardon sticking through my pants, my  bathing suit looks like a hutch ...

So I'm thinking to myself - Elias you walk away from  this, you gonna regret this the rest of your natural  life.  So I go after her, follow her down the beach.   You know find out if she is what she is. They're all hooked into this now.
And?
Well she was picking up her kids.
Dat's dat.

Get outta here, she married ...
Like two hogs in heat.  Boy. Their throats knotting ...

What didn't she do.  She fucked the living shit outta  me, that's what she did!
(sucking in air) Jesus!
Couldn't get enuff ...

She was a crossbreed, Chinese and Polish.
What dat?
(finally hooked in) And living in Hawaii man?
Yeah - and has blonde hair and almond-shaped eyes.
Hey man didn't you say she had black hair?

She had blonde hair man.  And long tan legs, in those  leather sandals you know, with those thongs up to her  knees, this musky oil on it ... mmmm smelled good  when they were wrapped around my face ... They groan, dreaming of Hawaii.
Yeah!
God!
Please, somebody hold my dick!
(in afterthought) ... and a broken nose.
Broken man?
Yeah, otherwise she would've been too perfect, y'know  what I mean ... some woman.  Her name was ... He forgets it.  A grass blackout.  Lerner urging him on.
Susan?
Tamara?
Elizabeth? Elias shaking his head, trying to remember.
Merle?
Merle?  Jesus!  ... Patty?
Inga?
Jennifer?
Connie? Elias snapping his fingers.
Dawn!  That was it!
(repeating it) Dawn ... King listening to the sound of it.
Dawn? The others nodding, musing over it.
Yeah, Dawn ...

In comparison to the darkness of the hooch, a highly lit  atmosphere, attracting bugs ... dusty gear lying around a disordered hooch, loud and finger-snapping COUNTRY WESTER playing from a tape deck, a well-known tune, circa 1967. BUNNY, the 18 year-old angel face, totters drunk with a C beer in hand, over to JUNIOR, the badass black kid with t who just lies there on his cot sweating, doing nothing.
